Yes, the Athenian Democracy excluded certain groups of people such as women, slaves, and non-citizens from participating in the political process, which seems unfair from our modern perspective. 

Citizenship was restricted to adult free-born males who had completed their military training. Women, slaves, and non-citizens were excluded from the political process because they were seen as inferior and unable to participate in civic life.

For example, women were believed to be inferior to men and were considered incapable of exercising citizenship rights. Slaves were not allowed to participate because they were not considered free and were seen as property rather than people. Non-citizens were also marginalized because they were seen as outsiders who did not have a stake in the community.

It is important to remember that Ancient Athens was a society that was very different from the modern world, and social norms and attitudes towards gender, race, and class were vastly different. While Athenian citizens valued democracy and participation in civic life, they did not see all members of their society as deserving of those rights.

It took centuries of social and political movements to begin to shift these attitudes and expand democracy to include more people.
